Gajengi Clinton S. Fernandes Bhalchandra M. Bhanage ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology, Matunga, Mumbai 400 019, India Department of Chemistry Institute of Chemical Technology Matunga Mumbai 400 019 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The present protocol reports a facile and efficient method of preparation for Cu2O/Ag nanocomposite (NPs) using ethylene glycol under microwave irradiation within a short duration of time. The synthesized Cu2O/Ag NPs well characterized by XRD, FEG-SEM, EDS and NH3-TPD, ICP-AES techniques. Futher, the catalytic application of Cu2O/Ag NPs for the synthesis of substituted pyrroles via multicomponent reaction (MCRs) by using an aldehyde, amine, 1,3-diketone and nitromethane at room temperature. The catalytic system provide good yields of products for a wide range of substrates. Also catalyst shows excellent catalytic recyclability without much loss of its activity. Keywords Cu2O/Ag NPs Pyrroles Multicomponent Heterogenous 1 Introduction The developments in nanoscience and nanotechnology due to their distinctive properties than that of the bulk of the compounds have a wider range of applications in the different fields and which also open up the new scope for nano metal oxide applications. The metal oxide nanomaterials have wider applications in water splitting, solar cells, supercapacitors, lithium ion batteries, fuel cells and catalysis [1,2]. Nowadays, the synthesis of size and shape selective nanomaterisls have great importance due to their unique features [3]. The synthesis and application of Cu2O/Ag NPs are in demand and have broad range of applications as immunosensors, photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, antibacterials and Raman scattering technology [4–7]. There are various methods have been reported for the synthesis of Cu2O/Ag composites as electron beam irradiation method, thermal decomposition, photocatalytic method, electrodeposition, hydrothermal, in situ solution synthesis, wet chemical reduction [8–14] etc. Multicomponent reaction (MCRs) is reactions in which three or more molecules react together to give the desired product in a one pot system. The MCRs have the advantage in terms of green chemistry and economic point of view because efficient, cost effective and less generation waste products as compared with the traditional methods. Due to fast and simple experimental procedure of MCRs useful for the synthesis of many heterocyclic compounds. MCRs catalysed by various catalysts for the synthesis of heterocyclic compounds such as pyrroles, pyridines, pyrazol-yl-pyrazolone methanes, 1,4-dihydropyridine, Propargylamines, N-sulfonylacrylamidines, benzoxanthenones [15–21] etc. Pyrroles and its derivatives are the important moities in the various biologically active compounds such as alkaloids, porphyrins, bile pigments, coenzymes, and pharmaceutical compounds [22–24]. The traditional methods for the synthesis of pyrroles and its derivetaives, which includes Hantzsch, Knorr and Paal-Knorr synthesis [25–27]. Recently, pyrroles synthesis catalysed by various metals and metal oxides has taken considerable attention [28]. The various catalytic systems were used for the synthesis of pyrroles including NiFe2O4, CoFe2O4, Fe-MIL-101, FeCl3, Silica gel supported tungstic acid, Amberlyst-15 and ionic liquids [29–35]. Also, the synthesis of pyrroles done by using various methods depending upon the available starting precursors [36–40]. These methods have one or more limitation such as expensive catalyst, longer reaction time, high reaction temperature, non-easily availability of starting materials, use of solvents, difficulty in recovery of the catalyst. To overcome these limitations there is still need to develop the green protocol, which works under the mild reaction conditions. Herein, we have reported a simple and covenient method for the synthesis of various Cu2O/Ag NPs using ethylene glycol under microwave irradiation and well characterized by using FEG-SEM, XRD, EDS and NH3-TPD, ICP-AES. Further, the catalytic application of Cu2O/Ag NPs for the one pot synthesis of pyrroles at room temperature using aldehyde, amine, 1,4-dicarbonyl compound and nitromethane via MCRs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents All chemicals and reagents of A. R. grade were purchased from SD Fine Chemicals Ltd., Mumbai, India and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of Cu2O/Ag NPs Copper nitrate trihydrate (187mg) was dissolved in 4mL ethylene glycol. With this solution 6mL of 0.01M AgNO3 solution was added and irradiated under the microwave at 600W for 4min which gives red to black precipitate which indicates the formation of Cu2O/Ag NPs which is designated as Cu2O/Ag-(A). The precipitate was separated by centrifugation at 8000rpm for 10min. The precipitate was washed with 20mL distilled water and then with 20mL of ethanol and dried in an oven at 80°C for 1h. Similarly, above same procedure was followed only change in the volume of 4mL of 0.01M AgNO3 and 8mL of 0.01M AgNO3 for the synthesis of Cu2O/Ag NPs which is designated as Cu2O/Ag-(B) and Cu2O/Ag-(C) respectively. 2.3 Characterization of Cu2O/Ag NPs The prepared Cu2O/Ag NPs were characterized using various analytical techniques such as FEG-SEM by Tescan MIRA 3. The energy dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDS) was recorded by using INCA x-act Oxford instrument (Model 51-ADD0007), XRD analysis was done by using Shimadzu XRD-6100, acidity by NH3-TPD by using thermo scientific TPDRO 1100, elemental composition was done by using ICP-AES (Spectro Analytic Instruments GmbH, Germany). 2.4 General procedure for synthesis of substituted pyrroles by one pot synthesis In a reaction vial, aldehyde (1mmol), amine (1mmol), 1,3-diketone (1mmol), 1mL of nitromethane and catalyst Cu2O/Ag NPs (5mg) were added. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15h. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. Upon the completion of reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The reaction mixture was extracted in the ethylacetate and concentrated under the vacuum. The products were purified by chromatograpgy. All the products are well known and reported in the literarure and characterized using GC–MS and compared with authentic samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Cu2O/Ag NPs The morphology of the synthesized Cu2O/Ag-(A) NPs was observed using an FEG-SEM. The Fig. 1 a which indicates the particles are in the spherical shape and in nano range. The elemental spectrum, which indicates the presence of copper, oxygen and silver, which confirm the pure form of Cu2O/Ag NPs with absence of any other impurites (Fig. 1b). The morphology of Cu2O/Ag-(B) and Cu2O/Ag-(C) are appers to be in the spherical shape (ESI, Fig. S1). X-ray diffraction analysis of Cu2O/Ag-(A) was performed with an X-ray wavelength of Cu Kα radiation at λ=1.5405Å with the scanning rate of 2°/min from 20° to 80° for Cu2O/Ag NPs (Fig. 2 ). Peaks corresponding to both Cu2O and Ag were observed in the XRD pattern. The lattice planes of (111) (200) (220) and (311) were corresponding to the FCC lattice of silver (JCPDS: 04-0783) [41] and (111) (200) (220) and (311) were corresponding to the FCC structure of Cu2O (JCPDS: 05-0667) [42]. Similarly, XRD of Cu2O/Ag-(B) and Cu2O/Ag-(C) analysed which are matches with the standard (ESI, Fig. S1). The acidity of prepared Cu2O/Ag-(A) NPs were calculated by using TPDRO 1100 thermo scientific. Before analysis of sample, sample is pretreated with helium gas at 200°C for 2h to remove moisture and other impurities on the surface of the catalyst and then cooled to room temperature. Then the sample was saturated with pure NH3 and then NH3-TPD started from room temperature up to 1000 °C with the temperature ramp of 10 °C/min with helium gas as the carrier gas. The amount of NH3 desorbed was 22110μmol/g which indicates the high acidity of the catalyst (Fig. 3 ). The elemental composition of Cu2O/Ag-(A) composite is done by using ICP-AES and the weight% of Cu and Ag found to be 75 and 10% respectively. 3.2 Catalytic application of Cu2O/Ag NPs for synthesis of substituted pyrroles by one pot synthesis The synthesized Cu2O/Ag NPs applied for the synthesis of highly substituted pyrroles by using aldehyde 1a, amine 2a, 1,3-diketo compound 3a and nitromethane in one pot. Initially, the four component reaction carried at room temperature for the synthesis of substituted pyrroles 4aaa. When the reaction carried out without an addition of the catalyst, trace amout of substituted pyrroles 4aaa observed (Table 1 , entry 1). When the reaction carred out with different ratios of Cu2O/Ag NPs such as Cu2O/Ag-(A), Cu2O/Ag-(B) and Cu2O/Ag-(C). When reaction carried out with Cu2O/Ag-(A) as a catalyst we got 98% yield of product 4aaa (Table 1, entry 2). Similary, when Cu2O/Ag-(B) and Cu2O/Ag-(C) utilized, we observed 90% and 98% yield respectively (Table 1, entries 3–4). We also carried out the reaction in the presence of alone Cu2O and alone Ag NPs, we observed only 63% and 70% yield of 4aaa (Table 1, entry 5 and 6). These above results shows that the presence of Cu2O and Ag both shows synergistic effects for the activation of reaction. By considering the activity and the composition of Ag, we choosed Cu2O/Ag-(A) as a catalyst for the further optimization study. Initially we studied the effect of catalyst loading, the use of 1mg of a catalyst provides the moderate yield of 4aaa (Table 2 entry 1). By the increasing amount of catalyst loading we found the increased yield of 4aaa (Table 2, entries 2–5). While, further increase in the catalyst loading from 10 to 20mg no any noticeable conversion were observed (Table 2, entries 6–8). Hence, we decided that the 5mg of catalyst loading was the optimium loading. Then, we studied the effect of time duration from 5 to 24h for the optimization study (Table 2, entries 9–16). The increase in time from 5 to 15h, the increased yield of the product 4aaa is observed. While, futher increase in time no change in the yield were observed (Table 2, entries 9–16). The final optimized reaction conditions is used for the synthesis of various derivatives of the substituted pyrroles (Table 3 ). The reaction of benzaldehyde 1a, benzylamine 2a, methylacetoacetate 3aa and nitromethane gave excellent 98% yield of product 4aaa (Table 3, entry 1). Then the change in the different substituents on benzaldehyde was studied such as 4-fluorobenzaldehyde 1b with 2a, 3a gave of product 4baa in a good yield (Table 3, entry 2). Next, reaction of aliphatic aldehyde as cyclohexanaldehyde 1c with 2a and 3a gave 88% yield of product 4caa (Table 3, entry 3). The heterocyclic aldehyde (pyridine 3-aldehyde 1d, furfural 2-aldehyde 1e) do not work under the optimized reaction conditions and they gave trace amount of product, but when the same reaction carried at 50°C gave the products 4daa-4eaa (Table 3, entries 4 and 5). Next studied the change in the 1,3-dicarbonyl compound such as ethylacetoacetate 3b and acetylacetone 3c also gave a good yield of products 4aab-4aac (Table 3, entries 6 and 7). Finally substituted pyrroles prepared by the using the cyclohexylamine 2b, butylamine 2c with 1a and 3a afforded the product in a good yield 4aba-4aca (Table 3, entries 8 and 9). 3.3 Recyclability study The one of the important study of heterogenous catalysis is the recyclability study. So we studied the recyclability for the synthesis of substituted pyrrole 4aaa under optimized reaction conditions. After the completion of the reaction the catalyst separated by centrifugation and washed with water, ethanol and dried under vacuum and further used for the reaction. It was found the catalyst Cu2O/Ag-(A) NPs showing good catalytic activity up to four consecutive runs without much decrease in its catalytic activity (Fig. 4 ). 3.4 The catalytic mechanism of Cu2O/Ag NPs for the synthesis of substituted pyrroles The proposed mechanism for the synthesis of substituted pyrroles catalyzed by Cu2O/Ag NPs has been shown in Fig. 5 . First, Cu2O/Ag NPs binds with the carbonyl group of 1,3-dicarbonyl compound then the carbonyl compound is activated. Then the formation of enamine A by reaction of activated carbonyl compound and amine. Further, the condensation of aldehyde with nitromethane give the compound B which then reacts with enamine A give the intermediate C. Finally, the intermediate C undergo cyclisation followed by elimation of HNO and H2O give the desired product [28,30]. 3.5 Comparison of catalytic activity of Cu2O/Ag NPs with other reported catalytic systems for the synthesis of substituted pyrroles The catalytic activity of synthesized Cu2O/Ag for the synthesis of substituted pyrrols is investigated by using recently reported methods (Table 4 ). In literature survey, we found various drawbacks such as utilization of high temperature [28,31], high catalyst loading [31], difficulties in recovery of catalysts [32] and complications in synthesis of catalyst [35] as compared to our method. 3.6 Characterization data of products 3.6.1 Methyl 1-benzyl-2-methyl-4-phenyl-1H-pyrrole-3-carboxylate (Table 3, entry 1) 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3) δ 12.45 (s, 1H), 7.31 (m, 2H), 7.17 (m, 1H), 7.10 (d, J =7.6Hz, 2H), 5.17 (s, 1H), 2.09 (s, 3H), 1.98 (s, 3H). GC–MS (EI, 70eV): m/z (%)=176 (6) [M+], 175 (45), 160 (100), 132 (56), 118 (38), 77 (35), 51 (19), 44 (39). 3.6.2 Methyl 1-benzyl-4-(4-fluorophenyl)-2-methyl-1H-pyrrole-3-carboxylate (Table 3, entry 2) 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3))δ 7.31 (dd, J =14.2, 6.8Hz, 5H), 7.09–6.96 (m, 4H), 6.55 (s, 1H), 5.05 (s, 2H), 3.66 (s, 3H), 2.46 (s, 3H). GC–MS (EI, 70eV): m/z =324 (10) [M+], 323 (43), 292 (8), 199 (6), 91 (100), 65 (8). 3.6.3 Methyl 1-benzyl-4-cyclohexyl-2-methyl-1H-pyrrole-3-carboxylate (Table 3, entry 3) 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3)) δ 7.33–7.23 (m, 3H), 6.97 (d, J =7.4Hz, 2H), 6.34 (s, 1H), 4.98 (s, 2H), 3.78 (s, 3H), 2.98 (t, J =11.7Hz, 1H), 2.38 (s, 3H), 1.98 (d, J =12.3Hz, 2H), 1.73 (t, J =16.5Hz, 3H), 1.61 (s, 1H), 1.44–1.34 (m, 2H), 1.24 (s, 1H), 0.87 (s, 1H), GC–MS (EI, 70eV): m/z =312 (11) [M+], 311 (49), 280 (5), 268 (14), 256 (26), 24 (34), 242 (10), 65 (9). 3.6.4 Ethyl 1-benzyl-2-methyl-4-phenyl-1H-pyrrole-3-carboxylate (Table 3, entry 6) 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.38 − 7.22 (m, 9H), 7.06 (d, J =7.3Hz, 1H), 5.68 (s, 1H), 5.06 (s, 2H), 4.14 (q, J =7.0Hz, 3H), 2.46 (s, 3H), 1.11 (t, J =7.0Hz, 3H), GC–MS (EI, 70eV): m/z =320 (15) [M+], 319 (63), 274 (17), 273 (16), 272 (22), 246 (4), 181 (9), 65 (8). 4 Conclusion In conclution, we have synthesized and characterized various Cu2O/Ag NPs by using ethylene glycol under microwave irradiation method within a short duration of time. This as-synthesized Cu2O/Ag NPs shows excellent catalytic activity for the one pot synthesis of substituted pyrroles using four component MCRs such as an aldehyde, amines, 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and nitromethane at room temperature. This catalytic system shows high activity towards the different functional group tolerance. Additionally, the catalyst shows excellent recyclability upto four consecutive cycles without loss of its activity. Acknowledgements Author Aravind L. coredata.dc:description: The present protocol reports a facile and efficient method of preparation for Cu2O/Ag nanocomposite (NPs) using ethylene glycol under microwave irradiation within a short duration of time. The synthesized Cu2O/Ag NPs well characterized by XRD, FEG-SEM, EDS and NH3-TPD, ICP-AES techniques. Futher, the catalytic application of Cu2O/Ag NPs for the synthesis of substituted pyrroles via multicomponent reaction (MCRs) by using an aldehyde, amine, 1,3-diketone and nitromethane at room temperature. The catalytic system provide good yields of products for a wide range of substrates. Also catalyst shows excellent catalytic recyclability without much loss of its activity.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of Cu2O/Ag nanocomposite and their catalytic application for the one pot synthesis of substituted pyrroles
